original: āryānityatā sūtram
analyzed: ārya anityatā sūtram
translated: Noble Sutra on Impermanence

original: om namaḥ sarvajñāya
analyzed: om namaḥ sarvajñāya
translated: Om, homage to the Omniscient One

original: evaṃ mayā śrutamekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyāṃ viharati sma jetavane'nāthapiṇḍadasyārāme mahatā bhikṣusaṃghena sārddhaṃ trayodaśabhirbhikṣuśataiḥ
analyzed: evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyām viharati sma jetavanena athapiṇḍadasya ārāme mahatā bhikṣu saṃghena sārddham trayodaśabhiḥ bhikṣu śataiḥ
translated: Thus have I heard. At one time, the Blessed One was dwelling in Shravasti, in the Jeta Grove, in the garden of Anathapindada, together with a great assembly of thirteen hundred and fifty monks.

original: tatra khalu bhagavān bhikṣūnāmantrayate sma
analyzed: tatra khalu bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayate sma
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the monks:

original: anityā bhikṣavaḥ sarvasaṃskārā adhruvā anāsvāsikā vipariṇāmadharmāṇaḥ /
analyzed: anityāḥ bhikṣavaḥ sarva saṃskārāḥ adhruvāḥ anāsvāsikāḥ vipariṇāma dharmāṇaḥ
translated: Monks, all conditioned things are impermanent, unstable, unreliable, subject to change.

original: yadyāvat bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyo'laṃ nirvartitumalaṃ viraktamalaṃ vimoktum /
analyzed: yat yāvat bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ ulam nirvartitum alam viraktam alam vimoktum
translated: Monks, it is enough to feel revulsion towards all conditioned things, enough to feel detached, enough to be liberated from them.

original: sarveṣāṃ sattvānāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāṃ prāṇināṃ āmaraṇānta hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇam /
analyzed: sarveṣām sattvānām sarveṣām bhūtānām sarveṣām prāṇinām āmaraṇānta hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: For all beings, all creatures, all living beings, life ends in death, there is no escape from it. For the born there is no escape from death.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo gṛhapatayo mahāśālakulā brāhmaṇa mahāśālakulākṣatriya mahāśālakulā āśāṃ mahādhano mahābhogāḥ prabhūtamaṇimāṇikyamuktāvaiduryaśaṃkhaśilāpravālajātarūparajatavikaraṇāḥ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ gṛhapatayaḥ mahā śāla kulāḥ brāhmaṇa mahā śāla kula a kṣatriya mahā śāla kulāḥ āśām mahādhanaḥ mahā bhogāḥ prabhūta maṇi māṇikya muktā vaidurya śaṃkha śilā pravāla jātarūpa rajata vikaraṇāḥ
translated: Monks, those householders from great merchant families, great brahmin families, and great ruling class families, who are wealthy, with great riches and property, with abundant jewels, gems, pearls, lapis lazuli, conch shells, quartz, coral, gold, silver, and other valuables,

original: prabhūtadhanadhānyakoṣakoṣṭhāgārasannicayāḥ prabhūtadāsīdāsakarmakara paurūṣeyo prabhūtamitrāmātyajñātisālohitāsteṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ jīvitamaraṇaṃparyavasānaṃ
analyzed: prabhūta dhana dhānya koṣa koṣṭhāgāra sannicayāḥ prabhūta dāsī dāsa karmakara prabhūta mitra amātya jñāti sālohitāḥ teṣām api maraṇa antam jīvita maraṇam paryavasānam
translated: They have abundant wealth, grain, treasuries, and storehouses. They have abundant female and male servants, workers, and employees. They have abundant friends, ministers, relatives, and kinsmen. Even for them, life ends in death. It ends in death.

original: nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāśca murddhābhiṣiktā jānapadai śvaryasthāmavīryamanuprāptā mahāntaṃ pṛthvīmaṇḍalamabhinirjityā vasanti /
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ca murddhābhiṣiktāḥ jānapadaiḥ śvarya sthāma vīryam anuprāptāḥ mahāntam pṛthvī maṇḍalam abhinirjitya ā vasanti
translated: Those who are kings, kshatriyas anointed on the head, who have attained sovereignty, power, and valor in the countryside, and who live after conquering a great circular land,

original: teṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: even for them, life ends in death. It ends in death. There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ ṛṣayo vānaprasthāḥ pramukta phalāhārāḥ prabhūktaphala bhojinaḥ pramukta phalena yāpanti teṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvita maraṇaparyavasānaṃ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ ṛṣayaḥ vānaprasthāḥ pramukta phala āhārāḥ prabhūktaphala bhojinaḥ pramukta phalena yāpanti teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam
translated: Those who are sages, forest-dwellers, who eat freely given fruits, who eat freely given fruits, who subsist on freely given fruits, even for them, life ends in death. It ends in death.

original: nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ kāmāvacāradevāścāturmahārājikādevāstrayāstriśāṃdevānāmāstuṣitādevānirmāṇaratayodevāḥ paranirmitavaśavartinodevāsteṣāmapi
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ kāmāvacāra devāḥ cāturmahārājikā devāḥ trayāḥ triśān devāḥ nāmāstuṣitāḥ devāḥ nirmāṇaratayaḥ devāḥ paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ devāḥ teṣām api
translated: Those gods who are in the desire realm, such as the Four Great Kings, the Thirty-Three gods, the Tusita gods, the gods who delight in creating, the gods who have power over the creations of others, they too

original: maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇa paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: have death as the end of life, death as the culmination. There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo rūpiṇo devāḥ prathamadhyānalābhino brahmakāyikā brahmapurohitā mahābrahmāṇaḥ dvitīya dhyānalābhina parītābhā apramāṇābhā ābhāśvarā
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ rūpiṇaḥ devāḥ prathama dhyāna lābhinaḥ brahmakāyikāḥ brahmapurohitāḥ mahābrahmāṇaḥ dvitīya dhyāna lābhinaḥ
translated: Those gods who are in the form realm, who have attained the first dhyana, such as the Brahmakayika, Brahmapurohita, Mahabrahma gods, who have attained the second dhyana, such as the Parittabha, Apramanabha, Abhasvara gods

original: stṛtīyadhyāna lābhinaḥparītaśubhā apramāṇaśubhā śubhakṛtsnā caturthadhyāna lābhinonabhrakā puṇyaprasavā bṛhatphalā avṛhā atapā sudṛśāḥ sudarśanā
analyzed: caturtha dhyāna lābhinaḥparītaśubhā apramāṇaśubhā śubhakṛtsnā caturtha dhyāna lābhinaḥ nabhrakā puṇyaprasavā bṛhatphalā avṛhā atapā sudṛśāḥ sudarśanā  /
translated: who have attained the third dhyana, such as the Paritta-shuba, Apramanashuba, Shubhakrisna gods, who have attained the fourth dhyana, such as the Anabhraka, Punyaprasava, Bhanatphala, Avreha, Atapas, Sudarsha, Sudarshana

original: akaniṣṭhāścadevāsteṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaṃ paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: akaniṣṭhāḥ ca devāḥ teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇam paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: and Akanishtha gods, they too have death as the end of life, death as the culmination. There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ ārūpiṇodevā ākāśānantaāyatanopagā vijñānantyāyatanopagā ākiṃcanyāyatanopagā naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanopagāśca devāsteṣāmapi
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ ārūpiṇaḥ devāḥ ākāśa ananta āyatana upagāḥ vijñā anantya āyatana upagāḥ ākiṃcanya āyatana upagāḥ naevasaṃjñā nāsaṃjñā āyatana upagāḥ ca devāḥ teṣām api
translated: Those monks who are formless gods, gone to the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the gods who have gone to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, even for them

original: maraṇāntahi jīvita maraṇaṃ paryavasāna nāsti jātasyāmaraṇa /
analyzed: jīvita maraṇam
translated: death is the end of life, there is no escape from death for one who is born.

original: traidhātukamidaṃ /
analyzed: traidhātukam idam
translated: This is the triple world.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo'rhantaḥ kṣīṇāsravā kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛtakaraṇīyā apahṛtabhārā anuprāptatvākāthā parikṣīṇabhavasaṃyojanaḥ samyagājñāsuvimuktacittāḥ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavoḥ hantaḥ kṣīṇa āsravāḥ kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛta karaṇīyāḥ apahṛta bhārāḥ parikṣīṇa bhava saṃyojanaḥ samyagājñāsu vimukta cittāḥ
translated: Those monks who are arhats, with defilements exhausted, who have done what had to be done, done what had to be accomplished, laid down the burden, attained their own goal, with fetters that bound them to existence completely severed, with their minds well liberated by right knowledge,

original: sarvacetovaśiparamapāramitāprāptāsteṣāmapi kāyanikṣepaṇadharmāḥ /
analyzed: sarva cetaḥ vaśi parama pāramitā prāptāḥ teṣām api kāya nikṣepaṇa dharmāḥ
translated: even for them this body has the nature of being cast aside.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhā khaḍga viṣāṇakalpā ekamātmāna damayanti ekamātmāna śamayati ekamātmātmānaṃparinirvāyanti teṣāmapi'yaṃkāyonikṣepaṇadharmaḥ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhā khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpāḥ ekam ātmāna damayanti ekam ātmāna śamayati ekam ātma ātmānam parinirvāyanti teṣām api yaṃkāyaḥ nikṣepaṇa dharmaḥ
translated: Those monks who are pratyekabuddhas, solitary like a rhinoceros horn, who tame themselves, who calm themselves, who attain final nirvana by themselves, even for them this body has the nature of being cast aside.

original: yepi te bhikṣavastathāgatā arhantaḥ samyak saṃbuddhādaśavalavalinaḥudārārṣamāḥsamyak siṃhanādanādineścaturvaiśāradyadharmārohaṇa vaiśāradyaṃ🔽sarvadharmadeśanāvaiśāradyaṃ nirvāṇamārgavatāraṇavaiśāradyaṃ āśravajñāna prahāṇāvaiśāradyaṃ /
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyak saṃbuddhāḥ daśa vala valinaḥ udāra ārṣamāḥ samyak  sarva dharma deśanā vaiśāradyam nirvāṇa mārga avatāraṇa vaiśāradyam āśrava jñāna prahāṇa avaiśāradyam
translated: Those monks, the Tathagatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, who roar the lion's roar of the noble truth, who proclaim the Dharma with the four forms of fearlessness, the fearlessness of

original: viśadādṛḍhanārāyaṇasaṃhatakāyāsteṣāmapyayaṃkāyonikṣepaṇa dharmaḥ /
analyzed: viśada adṛḍha nārāyaṇa saṃhata kāyāḥ teṣām api dharmaḥ
translated: the knowledge of the destruction of defilements, the fearlessness of the knowledge of the path leading to liberation, the fearlessness of the knowledge of the destruction of the defilements, and the fearlessness of proclaiming the time for attaining the fruits of asceticism,🔽whose bodies are firm and solid like Narayana's, for them too this body is subject to casting off.

original: tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhakārakṛtāni bhāṇḍāniśrāmānivāpakvāni va bhedanaparyantāni bhedana paryavasānānyevameva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣāṃ sattvānāṃ
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhakāra kṛtāni bhāṇḍa a niśrāmān iva apakvāni bhedana paryantāni bhedana paryavasānāni evam eva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣām sattvānām
translated: Just as, monks, all the vessels made by the potter, whether baked or unbaked, end in breaking, end in destruction, in the same way, monks, for all beings,

original: sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇināṃ āmaraṇāntaṃ hi jīvita maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: sarveṣām bhūtānām prāṇinām āmaraṇāntam hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya āmaraṇam
translated: for all creatures, for all living beings, life ends in death, ends in dying. There is no birth without death.

original: īdamavocadbhagavānnidamukto sugato hyathā parovāca śāstā /
analyzed: sugataḥ hi athā parovāca śāstā
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, this was said by the Sublime One. Having said this, the Teacher, the One of Vast Wisdom, further said this:

original: anityāvata saṃskārā utpāda vyayadhārmiṇaḥ /
analyzed: saṃskārāḥ utpāda vyaya dhārmiṇaḥ
translated: Impermanent are all conditioned things;🔽they arise and cease.🔽Having arisen, they cease;

original: utpādyahinirūdhyante teṣāṃvyapaśamaḥsukhaṃ //
analyzed: utpādya hi nirūdhyante teṣām vyapaśamaḥ sukham
translated: their pacification is bliss.

original: yathā hi kumbhakāreṇa muttikābhājanaṃ kṛtaṃ /
analyzed: yathā hi kumbhakāreṇa muttikā bhājanam kṛtam
translated: Just as a potter makes a clay pot,

original: sarva bhedana paryantaṃ sattvānāṃjīvitaṃtathā //
analyzed: sarva bhedana paryantam sattvānām jīvitam tathā
translated: so too is the life of beings subject to breaking.

original: yathāphalānāṃ pakvānāṃśaśvatpatanatobhayaṃ /
analyzed: yathā phalānām pakvānām śaśvat patanataḥ ubhayam
translated: Just as ripe fruits always have the danger of falling,

original: tathā saṃskārajāḥ satvā nityaṃ maraṇato bhayaṃ //
analyzed: tathā saṃskāra jāḥ satvāḥ nityam maraṇataḥ bhayam
translated: so too do beings born from formations always have the danger of death.

original: sarvekṣayāntā nicayāḥ patanāntāḥ samucchrayāḥ /
analyzed: sarva īkṣaya antāḥ nicayāḥ patana antāḥ samucchrayāḥ
translated: All accumulations end in exhaustion, all rises end in falls,

original: saṃyogāśca viyogāntā maraṇāntahi jīvitam //
analyzed: saṃyogāḥ ca viyoga antāḥ jīvitam
translated: all unions end in separation, and all life ends in death.

original: idamavocad bhagavānāttamanāste ca bhikṣavaḥ sā ca parṣadobhagavato bhāṣitamabhyanandan /
analyzed: idam avocat bhagavān ātta manāḥ te ca bhikṣavaḥ sā ca parṣadaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: The Blessed One said this, and those monks were delighted, and they rejoiced in the Blessed One's words.

original: ityāryānityatā sūtraṃsamāptaṃ //
analyzed: iti ārya anityatā sūtram samāptam
translated: Thus ends the noble Sutra on Impermanence.
